titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Rained almost all the forenoon.— Short walk however before dinner.— Mrs: Adams unwell— Count Panin called to see me this afternoon.— Told me a very extraordinary story, about Prince Dolgoroucky, one of his predecessors in the Russian mission to Berlin— At the tea-party given by Countess Reuss; only a few minutes— At the play in the Evening. The elopement from the Seraglio, an Opera: the music by Mozart.

2. Read the 6th: book of Wieland’s Oberon, into which he has introduced the story of January and May. I have not with me the second volume containing the 6 last books.— Short walk with Mrs: A. in the garden before dinner— Met Mr: Garvey, an Englishman lately arrived here— Visit at Count Panin’s after dinner— He received last evening a courier from Petersbourg, informing him of his appointment as Vice-Chancellor of the Empire— He goes, the day after to-morrow.— Walk again— At the tea-party, given by Madame de Werthern— At the play—The word of honour, a comedy, of no great worth.— Afterwards saw at the Hall, Jerome Pointu, indifferently recited, by some gentlemen of the company. The dialogue almost entirely their own— Chateaubourg one of the actors— Between 10 and 11. before we came home.

3. Writing all the morning— After dinner I walked to the Schlossberg and viewed the ruins— Upon the walls are great numbers of names written and carved in by persons who have visited the place; often with the date of the year when they came— Some of these dates are as far back as 1664, and prove the great length of time since which the castle has been in ruins. Evening at home; read some scenes of Shakespear’s Richard the 3d: to Mrs: Adams— Visit this forenoon from Mr: Garvey.

4. Writing to Mr: Murray.— In the afternoon walked with Mrs: Adams to the Schlossberg.— A great proof, how much her health has improved since we left Berlin.— We took some milk and beer, at one of the houses in the outside wall of the castle, which are still inhabited— As we came away we saw Countess Panin’s carriage; in which she had come quite to the top of the hill.— Evening at home.

5. Walked before dinner with Mrs: Adams to the fair, and in the afternoon round upon the hill, opposite the Prince’s garden; from which the prospect is beautiful, and constantly varying.— The weather is cold, and the air in general bleak

6. Walked again with Mrs: Adams before dinner, round the walls of the town; and in the afternoon to the garden at Dorn— Met Mr: Garvey.— Evening at the Play, and saw Don Juan or the speaking Statue, an Opera with the music of Mozart— I have seen it before, at the Hague— Have a cold.

7. Walk before breakfast; and with Mrs: Adams before dinner— In the afternoon we went to the tavern on the hill, where we took some milk; with bread and butter— Count Golowkin went away this morning. Visit to Count Brühl, who was not at home.— Walked again at the beginning of the Evening. finished reading Shakespear’s Richard the third.
8. Wrote all the forenoon. Walk with Mrs: Adams after dinner— We went round the Schlossberg, at the bottom of the hill— The exercise was rather too much for Mrs: A.— Evening at home.

9. Called in the forenoon to take leave of Count Brühl— Between one and two o’clock. after noon. we left Töplitz, and rode to Aussig, two German miles— The roads, are not bad, and by travelling this way, we avoid altogether the Geyersberg.— Count Brühl had written sometime ago to Dresden, to procure for us a boat to come and take us at Aussig, and carry us down the Elbe— We found the boat accordingly at Aussig, and had the carriage embarked in it, so as to be ready to go to-morrow morning at 5 o’clock.— Just before we left Töplitz, Countess Panin, and Countess Ozarowska, called on Mrs: A.— We have paid 24 florins a week for our apartments; consisting of five rooms upon a first floor, and a chamber for a servant, and having the furniture of every kind provided for us.

10. Just after 5 o’clock this morning, after passing an uncomfortable night, at the tavern at Aussig, we went on board our boat, which is built something like a dutch treck-schuyt, but is much smaller. We floated down the river with the current, assisted by three rowers.— At ten o’clock in the evening we arrived at Dresden.— Through the greatest part of the way the river runs through two very steep and lofty ranges of hills and rocks.— The towns of Tetschen, Schandau and Pirna; the fortress of Königstein, one of the strongest fortresses in Germany; the elector’s country seat at the famous Pilnitz, and a country seat belonging to count Thun, meet us on the road. After we passed the boundaries between Bohemia, and Saxony, we frequently passed people who were hewing stones from the immense rocks which border the sides of the river, for building at Dresden.— Upon our arrival, we immediately came to the lodgings taken for us by Mr: Errington; in the same house with his own.

11. Called early this morning at the banker’s, Mr: Gregory, to have the remainder of the Vienna Bank-bills, which I brought from Töplitz exchanged, which at his counting-house, they made some difficulty to do— Afterwards went with Mrs: A. to the fair, which was just closing as we arrived— We made however some purchases— After dinner we called at Countess Golowkin’s at the Hotel de Baviere. They were two nights, and three days, coming from Aussig, down the Elbe— We found at his lodgings, a large part of the company we used to meet at Töplitz; and also Mlle: de Bisschofswerder, and her mother.— We passed the Evening at Mr: Greathead’s; an English Gentleman, and family to whom Mr: Errington introduced us.— As we went in we met Mr: Elliott, the English Minister coming out.

12. Walk before breakfast with Mrs: A. in Count Brühl’s gardens. Their owner was father of Count Brühl our acquaintance; Minister to Augustus, king of Poland, and famous alike for his extravagant magnificence, and for his enmity to Frederic the second.— The ruins of a summer house in the Garden, testify the animosity at least of Frederic’s troops against the Count; as Dresden in general, bears marks of the sufferings which Frederic inflicted upon it, in the seven years war.— Walked again before dinner, and at the beginning of the Evening.— In the afternoon we spent an hour at the gallery of pictures— Read an act of Shakespear’s Henry the 8th: in the evening.

13. Went this morning to the gallery, and spent a couple of hours upon the Flemish school.— Mr: Errington went and introduced me at the resource, where we found Mr: Elliot; who offered to present me on Sunday next to the Elector at his Court, and desired me to sent him visiting cards, to be sent round, which I did accordingly— At home all the afternoon and Evening, Mrs: A— being very ill with an head-ache.

14. Paid visits this morning to Mr: Elliot, and Count Zinzendorf, neither of whom was however at home— Spent half an hour in the gallery.— At one, Mr: Elliot called on me, and took me to dinner at Count Lose’s, the Minister of foreign affairs— It was a dinner of ceremony given to Mr: Bibikoff, the Russian Minister, who has very lately arrived here; and as he is already recalled by his Government, it was at the same time the dinner upon his taking leave. The company consisted of about 25 persons, several of whom I knew before—Count Zinzendorf, Mr: and Madam de Bacounin, Baron de Rosenkrantz, Mr: and Mrs: Greathead, and their son.— Mr: Elliot came home with me; we found Mrs: A— at Mrs: Erringtons— We paid a visit to Countess Werthern, whom we found not at home— Evening, reading Henry the 8th:

15. A few minutes before noon, I went to the electoral Palace, and was there presented by Mr: Elliot, to Prince Max, the elector’s brother, his wife, a Princess of Parma, and the Elector’s sister, the Princess Mary Ann— And afterwards by an Audience to the elector and electress.— Mr: Bibikoff the Russian Minister had at the same time an Audience of leave, as had Baron Rosenkrantz, who has resided near here through the summer, and is upon his return to Berlin.— At four in the afternoon I paid a visit of form at Count Lose’s— The Countess only was at home— Went at five to an Assembly at the Governor’s, (of the City.) A numerous company, very much resembling the usual societies at Berlin— I came away just after eight, the time at which these assemblies usually break up.

16. Was at the gallery of pictures this morning, and continued my examination of the pieces of the flemish school.— Afterwards an hour at the resource, reading news-papers— Part of the Evening with Mr: Errington— Mr: Artaud there— Rainy weather nearly through the whole day.

17. At the gallery this morning, the weather being still too bad to allow going any where else— Wrote after I came home— Dined and passed the Evening with Mr: Errington— Mr: Prescott, and Mr: Greatheed and their families, Miss Elliot and several young Englishmen there.

18. Called this morning at the golden angel, upon Mr: Oliver, a young gentleman from Baltimore, who brought me yesterday a letter of recommendation from Mr: Pitcairn.— Afterwards at the gallery. Took a walk out of town— Walk towards evening with Mrs: A.— Finished readind Henry the 8th:
19. Mr: Oliver called on me, and we went together to the gallery. Walk afterwards. Mr: and Mrs: Errington and Mr: Oliver dined with us.— Miss Elliot passed the Evening with Mrs: A.

20. At the Gallery again this morning, and went regularly through the Italian school.— The great Raphael is undoubtedly the first picture in the collection— Dined & spent the eveg. at Mr: Greatheed’s.

21. This being an holiday (St: Matthew) the picture gallery was not open— Walk in the forenoon alone, and after dinner, with Mrs: A— round upon the ramparts of the town.— In the evening Mr: Garvey and Mr: Wright called upon us.— Reading cursorily the lives of the painters in this gallery.

22. Mrs: Adams went with Mr: and Mrs: Errington to the Catholic Church— At noon I went, first to the circle at Prince Maximilian’s (the Elector’s younger brother,) and afterwards to that of the Elector himself— Afterwards dined with the Elector; who invites alternately, his own, and the foreign Ministers every other Sunday.— Mrs: A dined with Mrs: Errington— After dinner I went up, and sat there an hour— Passed the Evening at Mr: Elliot’s, with a large company.— Countess Panin was there— Stayed to supper.

23. Went this morning with Mr: and Mrs: Errington, Mr: Artaud, and Mr: Oliver to see what is called the electoral treasure, consisting of a numerous collection of articles in silver, gold, and precious stones. The jewels of state which belonged to the electors ancestors when kings of Poland, and are now worn upon great occasions by the elector himself are the most valuable of these splendid baubles. Of diamonds, rubies, garnets, emeralds, sapphires, onyxes &c &c, there was no end.— A green diamond weighing 129. grams is said to be the only one of its kind in Europe. There are numerous sword-hilts, cane-pommels, epaulets, buckles, hat-loops, stars and crosses of the order of the golden fleece, buttons, lady’s necklaces, ear-rings, and breast knots, consisting entirely of brilliants, or rose diamonds. The value of this treasure is estimated at 15 millions of dollars.— Before going there I had called upon Mr: Oliver, and for an hour at the picture gallery— Dined with the Baron de Broekhausen, the Prussian Minister— He lives in the country; about a quarter of a mile out of town. Met there the young Count Finkenstein, a grand-son of the Minister, who is going to Vienna, as secretary to the Prussian legation there; and Count Dampmartin— Mr: and Mrs: Errington with us at tea, and in the Evening.

24. About two hours again this morning in the gallery—looking over again the best works of the Italian school.— Walk afterwards with Mr: Errington, and bespoke a thermometer— An hour in the afternoon at the Resource— Mr: and Mrs: Greatheed, Mr: & Mrs: Errington, Messrs: Parry, Wright, and Musgrave, at tea, and the Evening with us. Played backgammon with Mr: Greatheed.

25. At the gallery in the forenoon with Mrs: Adams, and in the afternoon alone. Met there Mr: Musgrave a young English Gentleman, who appears very well acquainted with the subject. Mrs: A. and Mrs: Errington took tea, and spent part of the Evening with Mrs: Elliot.

26. At the gallery from nine in the morning untill noon— Went to Lokowitz, a seat in the Country, about three miles from Dresden, where Count Schall, sometime resided— Mrs: and Miss Elliot; Mr and Mrs: Gray, Mr: and Mrs: Errington, were of the party— The house is elegant, and the Country around pretty, but not comparable to the landscapes, round Töplitz— Mr: Elliot, with Mr: Hunter and Mr: Long, were hare hunting near the same place. We returned to town, and dined between 6 and 7. o’clock at Mr: Elliot’s— Played Chess with him after dinner— It was after ten at night when we came home.— At about one in the morning, there was a cry of fire, which continued about half an hour.

27. At the gallery both morning and afternoon— Mrs: Errington dined and spent the Evening with us.— Read about half Shakspear’s Troilus and Cressida.— Walked out of one gate of the new town, and came in to another.

28. Was again at the gallery of pictures this forenoon; and in the afternoon with Mrs: Adams, to take our leave of it— On monday, it closes for the season.— I have here had leisure to view one of the finest collections extant of the Italian and Flemish schools, more attentively than I had ever an opportunity before.— It has given me a little further insight into the principles and history of the Art, or rather has served to convince me, how little I knew of them before, and how little in so short a time it is possible to acquire.— Evening at Mr: Errington’s with company— Read the first volume of Mrs: Radcliff’s Romance of the Forest.

29. Went to the Catholic Church, and heard mass performed.— It is a very elegant edifice, and is adorned internally with many altar pieces, by Raphaël Mengs; whom the Germans consider as the greatest of modern painters— The great altar piece, being the ascension of Christ, in presence of the apostles is his master piece.— After church we took a ride to the Planeschen grund, about 3 miles out of town, and where the landscape is very pretty.— In the evening we were at Mr: Elliot’s— Met there Mr: De Luc and an Abbé O’Kelly, an Irish priest, attached to the court.— Read the two remaining volumes of the romance of the forest.

30. We went this morning with Mr: and Mrs: Errington to see the public library, which is in the Japanese Palace over the bridge. The building is spacious and elegant— The library occupies two stories— The first and second floors.— It contains about 150,000 volumes, and in historical, theological and classical books, is very well furnished. They have a great number of valuable manuscripts, none of which were however shewn to us.— There is a collection of several thousand bibles of various editions and in all languages— One of them printed at Mentz, by John Fust, in 1464 was shewn to us, as the first edition ever printed— There was an Universal Lexicon, or Encyclopedia, in German, 64 volumes in folio, printed thirty years before the french encyclopedia, and probably the most voluminous work of the kind ever published.— In the cellars of this building we saw a great collection of Saxon, Japan, and Chinese porcellain; of which there was nothing curious but some specimens of the oldest porcellain made in Saxony, the secret for the composition of which is now lost.— We were also shewn several pieces of tapestry worked with the figures of Raphaël’s cartoons.— I afterwards called upon Count Brühl; and he not being at his lodgings, I walked to the electors garden out of town with Mr: Errington— We were caught in a shower and did not return home till after 3. o’clock. Dined at Mr: Errington’s with Mr: Greatheed’s family. In the evening, the company was numerous— Played backgammon with Mr: Greatheed.

Day. The ten first days, as the latter part of last month— Since being at Dresden, I have generally risen between 7 and 8. Written till 9. Breakfasted, dressed, and gone to the picture gallery untill twelve. Walked, or returned home and wrote untill 2.— Dined— In the afternoon have read or walked, or again attended the gallery— Evening mostly in company either at home, or abroad— Sometimes reading to Mrs: A.— Sup between 9 and 10, and soon after retire to bed.
